3 cups lukewarm water OR 4 c squash puree
8 cups King Arthur Unbleached All-Purpose Flour
1 tablespoon table salt or 1 1/2 tablespoons kosher salt
Add dry ingredients and mix until there are no dry spots; the texture of the dough should be fairly soft.
Knead gently a few minutes by hand or 1 to 2 minutes in a stand mixer; it'll be very sticky.
Cover and let dough rest at room temperature for 2 hours.
Refrigerate overnight or up to 7 days.
Scoop out 1 pound of dough (about a 1/4 of the batch) and place on a greased work surface.
Shape the dough into a rough, slightly flattened oval.
Fold the dough in half lengthwise and seal the edges with the heel of your hand.
Flatten slightly, fold lengthwise and seal again.
With the seam side down, cup your fingers and gently roll the dough into a 15-inch log.
Place the log seam-side down on a lightly greased or parchment-lined baking sheet, or in a baguette pan.
Cover and let rise till very puffy, about 1 1/2 hours.
Towards the end of the rising time, preheat your oven to 450°F.
Slash the baguette three or four times on the diagonal.
Spritz the baguette heavily with warm water.
Bake until a very deep golden brown, 25 to 30 minutes. Cool on a rack.
Add coconut water to blender first.
Add all fruit ingredients (berries, banana, orange, pineapple).
Add Greek yogurt and hemp seeds.
Blend on high until smooth and creamy.
Adjust consistency with more liquid or ice if needed.
Pour into a glass and serve immediately.
Melt butter on low heat, add chocolate and stir till melted together. Pour into a mixing bowl.
Add eggs and blend till velvety. (Use mixer.)
Add flour and salt, stir to combine.
Add chocolate chips. Whatever looks yummy.
Pour into greased 9x13 pan and bake at 350 for 25-30 mins, till toothpick inserted in the middle comes out with moist crumbs.
Remove brownies from oven. Pour bourbon over top. Let cool completely.
Chill em so they set up properly. Serve at room temp.
Put Marinade and chicken in a plastic bag, massage to cover evenly.
Stir together brown sugar, salt, yeast, and water. Let sit a few minutes till foamy.
Add eggs, olive oil, and flour.
Knead several minutes till smooth and soft. Electric mixer works best.
Let rise till doubled (about 1 hour), shape, let rise 30 minutes, bake.
Combine flour and spices in a plastic bag.
Put chicken (a few pieces at a time) in the bag and shake to coat.
Cook chicken, turning frequently, until browned and juices run clear (about 6–8 minutes).
Cut in the butter until crumbly.
Combine flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
Beat in egg, milk, and butter.
Spread into a greased 9-inch square pan.
3 chicken breasts, butterflied and pounded thin
Guac, salsa, and sour cream for serving
Put marinade and chicken in a bowl. Massage to cover evenly.
Cook chicken on both sides. Should be a nice golden brown.
Add chicken and cheese to quesadillas.
Heat a generous amount of oil in a skillet over medium.
Drop in your quesadilla and cook for about a minute and a half. Should be a nice golden brown.
Flip and do the other side.
My friend Ek's recipe. He was the chef at the Sentinel Marfa when I worked there.
Beat in eggs, evaporated milk, and vanilla extract.
Bake uncovered at 350° for 45 minutes, until almost set.
Combine oatmeal, brown sugar, pecans, cranberries, and melted butter.
3 packages (8 ounces each) cream cheese, softened
Press onto the bottom and 1 1/2 inches up the sides of the pan.
Place pan on a baking sheet and bake at 350° for 10 minutes.
Cool completely on a wire rack.
In a small saucepan, heat cream just to a boil.
Add chocolate chips. Let stand 5 minutes, then stir until smooth.
Beat cream cheese and sugar until smooth.
Add eggs and beat on low just until combined.
Stir in vanilla and the melted chocolate mixture just until blended.
Pour over crust. Put pan on baking sheet.
Bake 45-50 minutes or until center is almost set.
In a small heavy saucepan, heat cream just to a boil.
Cool pan on a wire rack for 10 minutes.
Run a knife around edge of pan to loosen.
1 pound carrots (about 3 medium carrots) sliced into 1/2 inch chunks
1 pound celery (about 5 stalks) sliced into 1/2 inch chunks, including leaves
2 leek, sliced and cleaned (white and light green parts only)
1 bunch fresh dill + 2 tbsp chopped fresh dill, divided
4 T good quality extra virgin olive oil
Combine all soup ingredients in a large pot.
Cover ingredients with 8 quarts water. Bring to a boil. (Takes at least 2 hours.)
Reduce heat to a simmer (around medium heat). Let the stock cook uncovered for 2-3 hours until the liquid reduces by a third and the stock is flavorful.
Remove everything except celery and carrots.
Add 2 T chopped dill. Adjust seasoning to taste, adding more sea salt if desired. Keep the stock warm till ready to serve.
Ladle the hot soup over the warm matzo balls.
Whisk eggs with vegetable oil and seltzer water.
Stir in everything up to dill.
Combine 6 quarts water with 2 pinches saffron and 2 T sea salt.
Bring to a simmer, stir to dissolve the salt. Keep hot until the matzo ball mixture is fully chilled.
Place a small dish of cold water beside the pot of saffron water.
Take batter out of fridge. Wet your hands and roll the matzo ball batter into walnut-sized balls, then gently drop them into the simmering water.
When all of the matzo balls are in the water, bring back to a low bubbling simmer (not a heavy boil) and cover the pot.

When fully cooked, turn off the heat and keep the matzo balls in the hot saffron water until ready to serve. (If you won’t be serving within an hour, remove the matzo balls from the pot with a slotted spoon and reserve so they don’t get mushy and fall apart.)
3/4 c grated havarti or fontina cheese
Heat skillet over low. Add butter.
Spread butter on bread. Sprinkle with everything spice and parmesan. Press to adhere.
Put cheddar and havarti on bread.
Put sandwiches in skillet. Cook until golden.
Combine brown sugar, sugar, and butter.
Add peanut butter, corn syrup, baking soda, and vanilla.
Add oats, chocolate chips, and M&Ms.
Drop dough onto an ungreased baking sheet.
Nonstick cooking spray or vegetable oil
2 teaspoons dried basil or Italian seasoning
Marinara or pizza sauce, for dipping (optional)
Adjust an oven rack to the top-third position and heat to 425 degrees. Line a sheet pan with parchment and coat with cooking spray.
In a shallow bowl or pie plate, beat eggs. On a large plate, combine panko, Parmesan, dried basil, garlic powder, ½ teaspoon salt and ¼ teaspoon pepper. Mix with a fork until well combined.

Trim ends of zucchini and cut into ½-inch-thick slices. Arrange on the baking sheet in a single layer. Sprinkle lightly on one side with salt and let sit for a few minutes, then blot with a paper towel. Flip zucchini and repeat salting and blotting on the second side.

Add a handful of zucchini slices to the beaten eggs, turning them a few times to coat. Transfer, one by one, to the panko mixture, allowing excess egg to drip back into the bowl. Turn zucchini a couple times in the panko, gently pressing the panko so it sticks. Return the coated zucchini to the baking sheet, evenly spaced apart. Repeat with the remaining zucchini slices until they’re all coated.
Bake zucchini for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and gently flip the zucchini with a spatula, then bake until lightly golden, 8 to 10 minutes.
Transfer to a platter and serve with marinara sauce for dipping, if desired.
Sift dry ingredients, add to mixture.
Inspired by Sara Coleman’s recipe from Mount Sinai Temple Sisterhood cookbook.
Shape into 1-inch balls, roll in sugar.
Press a Hershey's Kiss into the top of each cookie.
Anna has a variation of this where she encloses the Kiss inside the ball of dough. She calls them "Surprise Cookies".
Mix flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, cloves, cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger.
Beat butter with sugar on medium speed until just combined.
Add eggs one at a time. Beat each one in before adding the next.
Add dry ingredients and mix on low until well combined.
Pour the batter into the pan and smooth the top.
Set on a wire rack and let cool completely.
Beat butter with cream cheese on high speed until smooth and creamy.
Add powdered sugar and beat on low for 30 seconds, then switch to high speed and beat until light and creamy.
Spread the frosting on the cooled cake.
Ground Beef – We use 1.5 lbs of 80/20 beef to make 4 double-patty burgers, but you can easily scale the recipe up to feed a crowd (use 3 lbs for 8 double-patty burgers).
Sauce – A simple combination of mayo and yellow mustard is what we use to grill and assemble the burgers.
Cheese – We love thick-sliced medium cheddar cheese for burgers, but you can use American-style cheese or your favorite sliced cheese.
Buns – Brioche buns taste great and have that steakhouse burger look, but any burger bun will work.
Lettuce – Thinly slice your iceberg lettuce for a restaurant-style smash burger.
Pickles – Sliced dill pickle chips are the best.
Tomatoes – Select meaty and large-sized tomatoes for burgers and cut them into rings.
Red onion – Thinly sliced into rings.
Prepare Patties. Divide 1 1/2 lbs of ground beef into 8 equal portions (3 oz each), cover, and refrigerate until ready to cook.
Make Sauce. Stir together 1/3 cup mayo and 1 tsp mustard and set aside.
Toast buns. Lightly butter the cut side of your buns and toast on a griddle or skillet over medium heat until golden brown. Transfer to a rack.
Top buns. Place toppings on buns so you can add the burgers right from the grill.

Cook patties. Increase to medium-high heat. Depending on your surface area, place 2 to 4 cold pieces of meat onto the hot surface. Working quickly, cover each piece with a sheet of parchment paper and smash each into a thin patty. Remove parchment paper, season with salt, pepper, and garlic powder, add a dab of sauce, and flip. Sear for 2 minutes on the first side and about a minute on the second side.
Add cheese. Place a slice of cheese onto half of the patties and top with a second patty and remove from heat. Serve warm over toasted buns with toppings.
Shake the shit out of it.
Somebody ordered this while I was tending bar once. He called it a tequila daiquiri, but as far as I know it doesn't have an official name.
Put on floured surface and roll into a large rectangle about a half-inch thick.
Spread 2 T of butter over the dough.
Starting on the long edge, roll up the dough. Cut into one-inch thick slices.
Spread the rest of the butter on a half-sheet pan. Sprinkle with brown sugar and drizzle with corn syrup.
Place the rolls in the pan, cut side down.
Bake at 325 degrees for 20 minutes till nicely browned.
Bring butter and water to a boil; remove from heat.
Add rest of cake ingredients; stir until smooth.
Pour into a greased cookie sheet.
Bake at 325 for 15-17 mins, until cake is golden brown and passes the toothpick test.
Combine butter and milk; bring to a boil.
Remove from heat. Add sugar and extract; mix well.
Preheat oven to 325°F (163°C) and grease a 9-inch springform pan.
Combine graham cracker crumbs, melted butter, and sugar.
Press mixture into the bottom of the pan and refrigerate.
Beat softened cream cheese and sugar until smooth.
Mix in sour cream, vanilla extract, and flour.
Add eggs one at a time, mixing gently after each addition to avoid overbeating.
Pour the filling over the crust.
Bake for 55–65 minutes, until edges are set but center is slightly jiggly.
Turn off the oven and let the cheesecake cool inside for 1 hour.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours or overnight before serving.
Boil potatoes in a pot of water with 2 tsp salt. Simmer 20-30 minutes (depending on the thickness of potatoes), until tender.

Drain potatoes and transfer to a silpat lined baking sheet and cool for 10-15 minutes. Using a potato masher or the bottom of a drinking glass, gently press down on each potato, pressing to about 1/2" thickness and being careful not to break potatoes apart.
Drizzle half of the olive oil over one side of potatoes and sprinkle with half of the seasonings. Bake, uncovered, at 450°F for 12 to 15 minutes or until bottoms are lightly golden.
Turn potatoes with a spatula, drizzle with remaining oil and sprinkle with remaining seasonings. Bake 12 to 15 minutes or until potatoes are golden brown and crisp.
Sprinkle parmesan on potatoes and broil 2 to 3 minutes to melt the cheese.
Add milk and vanilla extract, mix
Slowly add flour and mix until just combined
